channel.title: Java logic question (try to answer)
channel.description:
Sooo for my computer science class 201 we had to create a question for people to answer using loops and decisions, try and give me the answer for the solution i want to make sure you have to answer it with a loop and a decision
thank you !
Let a person enter in an 'x' amount of games and the games scores using a while loop out print the highest score and the lowest score and the average
ex) How many games did you play : 4 Games score: 3 Games Score: 4 Games Score 3 Games Score 6
lowest : 3 highest : 6 average : 4
Thanks for helping me guys :D

Why not use a for loop? You know how many iterations to do, there’s no need for a while loop.
[/quote]

Because the op specified to use a while loop.[/quote]
Oh, my bad. I only read the first few lines.

try and give me the answer for the solution i want to make sure you have to answer it with a loop and a decision

Why not use a for loop? You know how many iterations to do, there’s no need for a while loop.

Because the op specified to use a while loop.

item.title: Java logic question (try to answer)
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“John459, post:10, topic:362625”]Well I’m guessing this would the simplest way to do it following what you said is required:

[code]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Game {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	int lowest = 0, highest = 0, numbers[] = null, count = 0; 
	float average = 0;
	Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in);
	System.out.println("How many games?");
	numbers = new int[s.nextInt()];
	System.out.println("Enter the scores");
	while (s.hasNextInt() && count < numbers.length) {
		int i = s.nextInt();
		if (count == 0)
			lowest = i;
		if (i < lowest)
			lowest = i;
		if ( i > highest)
			highest = i;
		average+=i;
		numbers[count] = i;
		count++;
	}
	average = (float) average/numbers.length;
	System.out.println("Lowest: " + lowest);
	System.out.println("Highest: " + highest);
	System.out.println("Average: " + average);
}

}[/code][/quote]
Why not use a for loop? You know how many iterations to do, there’s no need for a while loop.

Read full topic

item.title: Java logic question (try to answer)
item.dc:creator: @John459 John459
item.description:
@John459 wrote:

Well I’m guessing this would be the simplest way to do it following what you said is required:

[code]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Game {

public static void main(String[] args) {
	int lowest = 0, highest = 0, numbers[] = null, count = 0; 
	float average = 0;
	Scanner s = new Scanner(System.in);
	System.out.println("How many games?");
	numbers = new int[s.nextInt()];
	System.out.println("Enter the scores");
	while (s.hasNextInt() && count < numbers.length) {
		int i = s.nextInt();
		if (count == 0)
			lowest = i;
		if (i < lowest)
			lowest = i;
		if ( i > highest)
			highest = i;
		average+=i;
		numbers[count] = i;
		count++;
	}
	average = (float) average/numbers.length;
	System.out.println("Lowest: " + lowest);
	System.out.println("Highest: " + highest);
	System.out.println("Average: " + average);
}

}[/code]

item.title: Java logic question (try to answer)
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“Lin, post:8, topic:362625”]Or instead of creating 3 loops and teaching you bad habits you can use one and keep defined variables for the lowest, highest, and average. When looping through each variable, just check if it’s greater than the highest or lower than the lowest, and just add to the average where you would divide at the end… No real point in looping 3 times…

Also, it would even be better to do it as soon as you get the answer, as if you were already looping through. But, since you have to use loops, well, obviously you can’t do that. If your teacher expected something like Epic Steve’s code to be done, then punch him in the face.[/quote]
I said it was bad!

[quote=“bballin24, post:7, topic:362625”][quote author=Epic Steve link=topic=458912.msg3357745#msg3357745 date=1286065838]
No problem ^.^
[/quote]

ohh u used arrays rite… eep haha thats the next chapter haha do u know any way to do it without so i can actually present ure solution (ps. do u mind if i use ure solution in class for the arrays chapter )[/quote]
Sure, I don’t mind.

EDIT: This one also works, and doesn’t use three loops. Just the one.

import java.util.Scanner;


public class GameQuestion {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		GameQuestion game = new GameQuestion();
		game.scan = new Scanner(System.in);
		
		System.out.print("How Many Games?: ");
		game.logic(game.scan.nextInt());
		
	}
	
	public void logic(int len) {
		gameScores = new int[len];
		
		for(int i = 0; i < len; i++) {
			System.out.println("Game Score: ");
			gameScores[i] = scan.nextInt();
			
			if(i == 0) {
				lowest = gameScores[i];
			}
			
			if(gameScores[i] > highest) {
				highest = gameScores[i];
			} else if(gameScores[i] < gameScores[i-1]) {
				lowest = gameScores[i];
			}
			
			average += gameScores[i];
		}
		System.out.println("Higest: " + highest);
		System.out.println("Lowest: " + lowest);
		System.out.println("Average: " + average / gameScores.length);
	}
	
	Scanner scan;
	int[] gameScores;
	int highest = 0, lowest = 0;
	double average = 0.0;
}

Still uses arrays though.

Read full topic

item.title: Java logic question (try to answer)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

Or instead of creating 3 loops and teaching you bad habits you can use one and keep defined variables for the lowest, highest, and average. When looping through each variable, just check if it’s greater than the highest or lower than the lowest, and just add to the average where you would divide at the end… No real point in looping 3 times…

Also, it would even be better to do it as soon as you get the answer, as if you were already looping through. But, since you have to use loops, well, obviously you can’t do that. If your teacher expected something like Epic Steve’s code to be done, then punch him in the face.

Read full topic

item.title: Java logic question (try to answer)
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

This could probably be done much better, but I’m too tired 

import java.util.Scanner;


public class GameQuestion {

	public static void main(String[] args) {
		GameQuestion game = new GameQuestion();
		game.scan = new Scanner(System.in);
		System.out.println("Num Of Games: ");
		
		game.logic(game.scan.nextInt());
		
		System.out.println("Lowest: "+game.getLowest(game.gameScores));
		System.out.println("Highest: "+game.getHighest(game.gameScores));
		System.out.println("Average: "+game.getAverage(game.gameScores));
	}
	
	public int getLowest(int[] num) {
		int lowest = num[0];
		for(int i : num) {
			if(i < lowest) {
			    lowest = i;
			}
		}
		return lowest;
	}
	
	public int getHighest(int[] num) {
		int highest = num[0];
		for(int i : num) {
			if(i > highest) {
			    highest = i;
			}
		}
		return highest;	
	}
	
	public int getAverage(int[] num) {
		int sum = 0;
		for(int i : num) {
			sum += i;
		}
		return sum / num.length;
	}
	
	public void logic(int num) {
		gameScores = new int[num];
		for(int i = 0; i < num; i++) {
			System.out.println("Game Score: ");
			gameScores[i] = scan.nextInt();
		}
	}
	
	Scanner scan;
	int[] gameScores;
}

Read full topic
